sen.j: 検校（けんぎょう）とは、中世・近世の盲官の最高位の名称。
sen.e: Kengyo (検校: one of officers governing Shoen manor) is the highest title of the official rank for the blind officers in the middle and early modern ages.
sen.cmt: 盲官→定訳不明：mokan (blind officers)としました。
sen.e: Kengyo (検校：one of the officers governing Shoen manor) is the highest title of official rank for blind officers during the middle and early modern ages.
Kengyo (one of the officers governing Shoen manor) is the highest title of official rank for blind officers during the middle and early modern ages.

sen.j: 元々は平安時代・鎌倉時代に置かれた寺院や荘園の事務の監督役職名であったが室町時代以降、盲官の最高位の名称として定着した。
sen.e: Originally, it referred to the post of a manger administrating the office duties in the temples or Shoen (private estates) set in the Heian Period and the Kamakura Period, and was established as the highest title of the blind officers in the Muromachi Period.

The term Kengyo originally referred to the manager who administered office duties in temples or Shoen (private estates) during the Heian and Kamakura Periods, but from the Muromachi Period onwards, it was established as the highest title for blind officers.
sen.cmt: changed "it" to a clearer subject; changed sentence structure to describe the periods in more detail
sen.e: The term Kengyo originally referred to the manager who administered office duties in temples or Shoen (private estates) during the Heian and Kamakura periods, but from the Muromachi period onwards, it was established as the highest title for blind officers.
sen.cmt: スペース削除用語統一

sen.j: 検校は、専用の頭巾・衣類・杖などの所有が許された。
sen.e: Kengyo was allowed to carry a special hood, cloth, and stick.
Kengyo were allowed to wear special clothes with a hood and carry a walking stick.
Kengyo were allowed to wear special clothes with a hood and carry a walking stick.

sen.j: 盲官（盲人の役職）では、位階順に別当、勾当、座頭があった。
sen.e: Among the ｍokan (officers with blindness), there were betto (the superior of a temple), Koto (the third title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild of the blind), zato (the fourth title of the official ranks among blind officers, later among Todo-za, the traditional guild of the blind), in ranking order.

Among the mokan (blind officers), there were betto (superiors of a temple), koto (the third title of official rank within the Todo-za - the traditional guild of the blind), and zato (the fourth title) in order of rank.
sen.cmt: eliminated double parenthesis with a "-"; I don't know where to find information on these ranks, but I am wondering where the "2nd" rank is…
sen.e: Among the mokan (blind officers), there were betto (superiors of a temple), koto (the third title of official rank within the Todo-za - the traditional guild of the blind), and zato (the fourth title) in order of rank.

sen.j: 起源
sen.e: Origin
Origin
Origin

sen.j: 仁明天皇の子である人康親王が若くして失明し、そのため出家して山科（現在京都市山科区）に隠遁した。
sen.e: As Imperial Prince Saneyasu, a son of Emperor Ninmyo, became blind, when he was still young, he entered the priesthood to live a cloistered life in Yamashina (present Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City).

As the son of Emperor Ninmyo, Imperial Prince Saneyasu became blind while he was still young and entered the priesthood to live a cloistered life in Yamashina (present day Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City).

As the son of Emperor Ninmyo, Imperial Prince Saneyasu became blind while he was still young and entered the priesthood to live a cloistered life in Yamashina (present day Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City).

sen.j: その時に人康親王が盲人を集め、琵琶や管絃、詩歌を教えた。
sen.e: At that time, Imperial Prince Saneyasu invited the blind people to teach them biwa (Japanese lute), wind and string instruments, and poems.
As he entered the priesthood, Imperial Prince Saneyasu gathered the blind to teach them to play the biwa (Japanese lute), wind and string instruments and to recite poems.
sen.cmt: At that time→As he entered the priesthood; invited→gathered; fixed grammar
sen.e: As he entered the priesthood, Imperial Prince Saneyasu gathered the blind to teach them to play the biwa (Japanese lute), wind and string instruments and to recite poems.

sen.j: 人康親王の死後、側に仕えていた盲人に検校と勾当の2官が与えられた。
sen.e: After the death of Imperial Prince Saneyasu, the two blind retainers who had served to the prince were given the titles, Kengyo and Koto, respectively.
After the death of the Prince, the two blind retainers who had served at his side were each given the titles Kengyo and Koto.
sen.cmt: respectively→changed to "each" and moved to earlier spot in the sentence;
sen.e: After the death of the Prince, the two blind retainers who had served at his side were each given the titles Kengyo and Koto.

sen.j: これが検校と呼ばれる盲官の始まりとされている。
sen.e: It is said that this is the origin of the blind officer called Kengyo.
It is claimed that this is the origin of the blind officer named Kengyo.
sen.cmt: It is said→It is claimed; called→named
sen.e: It is claimed that this is the origin of the blind officer named Kengyo.

sen.j: また、人康親王が坐って琵琶を弾いたとされる琵琶石は後に盲人達により琵琶法師の祖神として諸羽神社に祭られている。
sen.e: A stone called Biwaishi (Japanese lute stone), on which it is said that Imperial Prince Saneyasu sat and played the Japanese lute (biwa), was enshrined in Moroha-jinja Shrine by the blind as a guardian for the biwa hoshi (biwa players).
sen.cmt: 琵琶法師→定訳不明：biwa hoshi (monk-style biwa players)としました。
sen.e: A stone called Biwaishi (Japanese lute stone), on which Imperial Prince Saneyasu allegedly sat and played the biwa, was enshrined in Moroha Shinto Shrine by the blind as a guardian for biwa hoshi (biwa players).

A stone called Biwaishi (Japanese lute stone), on which Imperial Prince Saneyasu allegedly sat and played the biwa, was enshrined in Moroha Shinto Shrine by the blind as a guardian for biwa hoshi (biwa players).

sen.j: 「法師」と呼ばれるのは、検校は剃髪し、正式な検校専用服(検校服)は僧服に近く、また実際に僧職となる者もいたからである。
sen.e: The name 'hoshi' (biwa players in monk's vesture) derives from the fact that Kengyo shaved his head and wore a officially designated cloth for Kengyo (cloth of Kengyo) similar to a Buddhist monk, and in addition, even some of them really went into the priesthood.

The term 'hoshi' (biwa players in monk attire) derives not only from Kengyo shaving his head and wearing officially designated Kengyo clothing that was similar to monk attire, but also because a number of hoshi did in fact join the priesthood.
sen.cmt: vesture→attire; I had to add "not only" near the beginning to keep this as one, flowing sentence.
sen.e: The term 'hoshi' (biwa players in monk attire) derives not only from Kengyo shaving his head and wearing officially designated Kengyo clothing that was similar to monk attire, but also because a number of hoshi did in fact join the priesthood.

sen.j: 室町時代
sen.e: Muromachi Period
Muromachi Period
Muromachi period

sen.j: 室町時代に検校明石覚一が『平家物語』をまとめ、また、足利氏の一門であったために室町幕府から庇護を受け、当道座を開き、検校は当道座のトップを務めた。
sen.e: In the Muromachi Period Kengyo Kakuichi Akashi compiled "Heike Monogatari" (The Tale of the Heike), and he, who was from a family of the Ashikaga clan, set up Todo-za (the traditional guild of the blind), in which Kengyo presided the top under the protection of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

During the Muromachi Period, Kengyo Kakuichi Akashi compiled "Heike Monogatari" (The Tale of the Heiki), and because he was from a family of the Ashikaga clan, he set up the Todo-za where he presided under the protection of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by the shogun).
sen.cmt: In→During; eliminated Todo-za information in parenthesis as it is written above;
sen.e: During the Muromachi period, Kengyo Kakuichi AKASHI compiled "Heike Monogatari" (The Tale of the Heike), and because he was from a family of the Ashikaga clan, he set up the Todo-za where he presided under the protection of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by the shogun).
sen.cmt: 用語統一人名修正スペル

sen.j: 江戸時代
sen.e: Edo Period
Edo Period
Edo period

sen.j: 江戸時代に入ると、幕府は盲人が当道座に属することを奨励し、当道組織が整備され、寺社奉行の管轄下ではあるがかなり自治的な運営が行なわれた。
sen.e: In the Edo Period, the bakufu encouraged the blind to belong to the Todo-za, consolidating the organization of Todo-za, and started to enjoy a considerable autonomy even though it was under the jurisdiction of Jisha-bugyou (magistrate of temples and shrines).

During the Edo Period, the bakufu encouraged the blind to join the Todo-za, consolidating the organization which started to enjoy considerable autonomy even though it was under the jurisdiction of the Jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines).

During the Edo period, the bakufu encouraged the blind to join the Todo-za, consolidating the organization which started to enjoy considerable autonomy even though it was under the jurisdiction of the Jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines).

sen.j: 検校の権限は大きなものとなり、社会的にもかなり地位が高く、当道の統率者である惣録検校になると十五万石程度の大名と同等の権威と格式を持っていた。
sen.e: Kengyo became to have an big authority with considerably high social rank, and a Soroku kengyo (chief kengyo), who lead Todo, was given the level of the authority and prestige comparable to those of a daimyo with the stipend of 150 thousand koku (a unit of the crop yield, rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter, lumber 1-koku is 0.278 cubic meter).
sen.cmt: 石→単位の説明として、koku (a unit of the crop yield, rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter, lumber 1-koku is 0.278 cubic meter)としました。
sen.e: Kengyo began to have considerable power and authority with a substantially high rank, and when someone became a Soroku Kengyo (chief kengyo) who lead the Todo-za, they were given the level of authority and prestige comparable to a daimyo with a stipend of 150 thousand koku (a unit of a crop yield - one rice koku is 180.39 liters; one lumber koku is 0.278 cubic meters).
sen.cmt: lead Todo→lead the Todo-za; fixed grammar
sen.e: Kengyo began to have considerable power and authority with a substantially high rank, and when someone became a Soroku Kengyo (chief kengyo) who lead the Todo-za, they were given the level of authority and prestige comparable to a daimyo with a stipend of 150 thousand koku (a unit of a crop yield - one rice koku is 180.39 liters; one lumber koku is 0.278 cubic meters).

sen.j: 当道座に入座して検校に至るまでには73の位階があり、検校には十老から一老まで十の位階があった。
sen.e: Todo-za had 73 ranks from admission to Kengyo, and Kengyo was divided into ten sub-ranks from Ju-ro (10th Senior) to Ichi-ro (1st Senior).
sen.cmt: 十老→定訳不明：Ju-ro (10th Senior) としました。 一老→定訳不明：Ichi-ro (1st Senior)としました。
sen.e: There were 73 ranks between admittance to Toda-za and the rank of Kengyo, with the rank of Kengyo being divided further into ten sub-ranks from Ichi-ro (1st senior) to Ju-ro (10th Senior).
sen.cmt: reversed "Ichi-ro" and "Ju-ro" because it feels more natural to have the higher rank named first; changed sentence structure to read more smoothly
sen.e: There were 73 ranks between admittance to Toda-za and the rank of Kengyo, with the rank of Kengyo being divided further into ten sub-ranks from Ichi-ro (1st senior) to Ju-ro (10th Senior).

sen.j: 当道の会計も書記以外はすべて視覚障害者によって行なわれたが、彼らの記憶と計算は確実で、一文の誤りもなかったという。
sen.e: All the accounting jobs of Todo were carried out by the persons with visual and hearing disabilities, except for clerical work, and it is said that their memory and calculation skills were so precise that there was not even a slight mistake.

Aside from clerical work, all accounting jobs at Todo-za were carried about by persons with visual and hearing disabilities, and it was revealed that their memory and calculation skills were so precise that not even the slightest inaccuracy could be found.
sen.cmt: changed structure a little and fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: Aside from clerical work, all accounting jobs at Todo-za were carried about by persons with visual and hearing disabilities, and it was revealed that their memory and calculation skills were so precise that not even the slightest inaccuracy could be found.

sen.j: また、視覚障害は世襲とはほとんど関係ないため、平曲、三絃や鍼灸の業績が認められれば一定の期間をおいて検校まで73段に及ぶ盲官位が順次与えられた。
sen.e: Since the visual and hearing disabilities had almost nothing to do with the heredity, once his achievement in heikyoku (a traditional musical narration on the Tale of Heike), sangen (or samisen: three-stringed instrument), acupuncture was recognized, the 73 ranks for the blind officers up to Kengyo were orderly given one by one in series with a certain interval of time.

As visual and hearing disabilities had almost nothing to do with heredity, once a member of the Todo-za was recognized for his achievements in heikyoku (a traditional musical narative on the Tale of Heike), sangen (or samisen -a three ringed instrument) and acupuncture, the 73 ranks up to Kengyo were sequentially opened up to the blind officers after certain intervals of time.
sen.cmt: orderly given one by one→sequentially; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: As visual and hearing disabilities had almost nothing to do with heredity, once a member of the Todo-za was recognized for his achievements in heikyoku (a traditional musical narrative on the Tale of Heike), sangen (or samisen -a three ringed instrument) and acupuncture, the 73 ranks up to Kengyo were sequentially opened up to the blind officers after certain intervals of time.

sen.j: しかしそのためには非常に長い年月を必要とするので、早期に取得するため金銀による盲官位の売買も公認されたために、当道座によって各盲官位が認定されるようになった。
sen.e: However, it needed a very long time to achieve such a promotion, buying and selling the blind officers' ranks by gold and silver currencies came to be admitted to accelerate the acquisition of higher ranks, and thus the ranks had to be accredited by Todo-za.

However, since it took a greatly extended amount of time to a receive such a promotion, in order to accelerate the acquisition of higher ranks, blind officers were authorized to trade gold and silver currency for higher ranks, which lead to the ranks being certified by the Todo-za.
sen.cmt: accredited→certified; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: However, since it took a greatly extended amount of time to receive such a promotion, in order to accelerate the acquisition of higher ranks, blind officers were authorized to trade gold and silver currency for higher ranks, which lead to the ranks being certified by the Todo-za.

sen.j: 検校になるためには平家物語平曲・地歌三弦・箏曲等の演奏、作曲、あるいは鍼灸・按摩ができなければならなかったとされる。
sen.e: To be Kengyo, it is said that one had to know playing heikyoku of the 'Tale of Heike,' jiuta sangen (a category of traditional Japanese song accompanied with sangen) and sokyoku (music played on the koto (a kind of harp)), as well as composition, or have skills of acupuncture and massage, but later in the Edo Period, heikyoku, which had been the representative accomplishment of Todo-za, became less popular, and in stead, jiuta sangen, sokyoku and acupuncture became Kengyo's practical skills required as professional.
sen.cmt: 地歌三弦→定訳不明：jiuta sangen (a category of traditional Japanese song accompanied with sangen)としました。 箏曲→sokyoku (music played on the koto (a kind of harp))としました。
sen.e: To become Kengyo, one had to be able to perform heikyoku (a traditional musical narration on the Tale of Heiki), jiuta sangen (a traditional Japanese song accompanied by a sangen) and sokyoku (music played on the koto - a kind of harp), as well as have skills in composition or acupuncture and massage. Later in the Edo period however, heikyoku, which had been the exemplary accomplishment of Todo-za, had lost its popularity, and juita sangen, sokyoku and acupuncture became the practical skills required to become a Kengyo professional instead.
sen.cmt: I could not keep this as one sentence because it was just too long; know playing→be able to perform; representative→exemplary; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: To become Kengyo, one had to be able to perform heikyoku (a traditional musical narration on the Tale of Heike), jiuta sangen (a traditional Japanese song accompanied by a sangen) and sokyoku (music played on the koto - a kind of harp), as well as have skills in composition or acupuncture and massage.
sen.cmt: 用語統一一原文一訳文の例外対処スペル

sen.j: しかし、江戸時代には当道座の表芸たる平曲は下火になり、代わって地歌三弦や箏曲、鍼灸が検校の 実質的な職業となった。
sen.e: Later in the Edo period, however, heikyoku, which had been the exemplary accomplishment of Todo-za, had lost its popularity, and jiuta sangen, sokyoku and acupuncture became the practical skills required to become a Kengyo professional instead.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処スペル

sen.j: ただしすべての当道座員が音楽や鍼灸の才能を持つ訳ではないので、他の職業に就く者や、後述するような金融業を営む者もいた。
sen.e: However, not all the members of Todo-za were talented in music or acupuncture, there were persons who changed their profession or entered into the financial business as mentioned below.
Not all members of the Todo-za were talented in music and acupuncture however, and there were some who changed their profession or entered into the financial business.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: Not all members of the Todo-za were talented in music and acupuncture however, and there were some who changed their profession or entered into the financial business as mentioned below.

sen.j: 最低位から順次位階を踏んで検校になるまでには総じて719両が必要であったという。
sen.e: It is said that to be Kengyo through step-by-step promotion, one needed 719 ryo (unit of currency gold) in total, starting form the lowest rank,
sen.cmt: 両→ryo (unit of currency gold)としました。
sen.e: It is estimated that to become Kengyo by being promoted through each sequential rank from lowest to highest, it costed a total of 719 ryo (unit of gold currency).
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: It is estimated that to become Kengyo by being promoted through each sequential rank from lowest to highest, it costed a total of 719 ryo (unit of gold currency).

sen.j: 江戸では当道の盲人を、検校であっても「座頭」と総称することもあった。
sen.e: In Edo, the blind of Todo including Kengyo were sometimes collectively called 'Zato.'
In Edo, the blind officers of Todo-za, including Kengyo, were sometimes collectively referred to as "Zato."
sen.cmt: the blind→the blind officers; Todo→Todo-za; added commas
sen.e: In Edo, the blind officers of Todo-za, including Kengyo, were sometimes collectively referred to as 'Zato.'

sen.j: 江戸時代には地歌三弦、箏曲、胡弓楽、平曲のプロフェッショナルとして、三都を中心に優れた音楽家となる検校が多く、近世邦楽大発展の大きな原動力となった。
sen.e: In the Edo Period, there were many Kengyo who were active especially in three capital cities as excellent professional musicians in jiutasangen, sokyoku, kokyu (Chinese fiddle) music and heikyoku, and thus they played an important role as a driving power in the development of Japanese music in the early modern ages.

During the Edo Period, there were many Kengyo who became excellent musicians in the three capital cities as professionals of juita sangen, sokyoku, kokyu (Chinese fiddle) music and heikyoku, which lead to them having an important role as a driving power in the development of Japanese music in the modern ages.
sen.cmt: change structure slightly to read more smoothly; eliminated "were active" as I do not see Japanese with that meaning
sen.e: During the Edo period, there were many Kengyo who became excellent musicians in the three capital cities as professionals of jiuta sangen, sokyoku, kokyu (Chinese fiddle) music and heikyoku, which lead to them having an important role as a driving power in the development of Japanese music in the modern ages.

sen.j: 磐城平藩の八橋検校、尾張藩の吉沢検校などのように、専属の音楽家として大名に数人扶持で召し抱えられる検校もいた。
sen.e: Among them there are some Kengyo who were employed by daimyo (feudal lord) as a in-house musician with a stipend equivalent to an annual crop volume enough to support several persons, like Kengyo YATSUHASHI in the Iwakitaira Domain, and Kengyo YOSHIZAWA in the Owari Domain.

There were some Kengyo who were employed by daimyo (feudal lord) as in-house musicians with a stipend equivalent to an annual crop volume large enough to support several people, such as Kengyo YATSUHASHI in the Iwakitaira Domain and Kengyo YOSHIZAWA in the Owari Domain.
sen.cmt: changed beginning of the sentence; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: There were some Kengyo who were employed by daimyo (feudal lord) as in-house musicians with a stipend equivalent to an annual crop volume large enough to support several people, such as Kengyo Yatsuhashi in the Iwakitaira Domain and Kengyo Yoshizawa in the Owari Domain.

sen.j: また鍼灸医として活躍したり、学者として名を馳せた検校もいる。
sen.e: Among Kengyo, there were also those who were active as acupuncture doctors, or those who became famous as scholars.
Furthermore, there were also Kengyo who were successful as acupuncture doctors and others who became famous as scholars.
Furthermore, there were also Kengyo who were successful as acupuncture doctors and others who became famous as scholars.

sen.j: その一方で、官位の早期取得に必要な金銀収入を容易にするため、元禄頃から幕府により高利の金貸しが認められていた。
sen.e: On the other hand, to facilitate the income in gold and silver, which was necessary to acquire the official ranks, bakufu permitted them to practice money lending at high interest since around the Genroku era.
On the other hand, to facilitate the income of gold and silver needed to quickly acquire official ranks, the bakufu permitted them to be money lenders with high interest rates during the Genroku era.
sen.cmt: added "quickly" and "rates"; fixed grammer to read more smoothly
sen.e: On the other hand, to facilitate the income of gold and silver needed to quickly acquire official ranks, the bakufu permitted them to be money lenders with high interest rates during the Genroku era.

sen.j: これを座頭金または官金と呼んだが、特に幕臣の中でも禄の薄い御家人や小身の旗本等に金を貸し付けて、暴利を得ていた検校もいた。
sen.e: These money lending were called Zatokin (zato's money) or Kankin (officer's money), and there were some kengyos who lent money to the gokenin (immediate vassal of the shogunate) with a scarce stipend or to the small hatamoto (direct vassals of the shogun) to make undue profits.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 座頭金→定訳不明：Zatokin (zato's money)としました。 官金→定訳不明：Kankin (officer's money)としました。
sen.e: This money lending was referred to as Zatokin (Zato money) or Kankin (officer money), with some Kengyo lending money to gokenin (immediate vassals of the shogunate) or low-ranking hatamoto (direct vassals of the shogun) and making excessive profits.
sen.cmt: undue→excessive; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: This money lending was referred to as Zatokin (Zato money) or Kankin (officer money), with some Kengyo lending money to gokenin (immediate vassals of the shogunate) or low-ranking hatamoto (direct vassals of the shogun) with a low stipend and making excessive profits.

sen.j: 安永年間には名古屋検校が十万数千両、鳥山検校が一万五千両等、多額の蓄財をなした検校も相当おり、吉原での豪遊等で世間を脅かせた。
sen.e: During the Anei era, there were kengyos who accumulated a large amount of fortune, like Kengyo NAGOYA who accumulated more than 105 thousand ryo, and Kengyo TORIYAMA who accumulated 15 thousand ryo, and they astonished the society by going on a spree at Yoshiwara (red-light district in Edo).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 吉原→定訳不明：Yoshiwara (red-light district in Edo)としました。
sen.e: During the Anei Era, there were Kengyo who accumulated a large fortune, such as Kengyo NAGOYA, who accumulated more than 105 thousand ryo, and Kengyo TORIYAMA, who accumulated 15 thousand ryo and astonished society by going on a spree at Yoshiwara (the red-light district in Edo).
sen.cmt: added commas and fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: During the Anei era, there were Kengyo who accumulated a large fortune, such as Kengyo Nagoya, who accumulated more than 100 thousand ryo, and Kengyo Toriyama, who accumulated 15 thousand ryo and astonished society by going on a spree at Yoshiwara (the red-light district in Edo).

sen.j: 同七年にはこれら八検校と二勾当があまりの悪辣さのため、全財産没収の上江戸払いの処分を受けた。
sen.e: In 1778, eight kengyos and two kotos were punished by expulsion from Edo after the forfeiture of whole the asset, for their excessively unscrupulous means to make profits.
In 1778, eight Kengyo and two Koto were banished from Edo after forfeiting all of their assets for their excessively underhanded means of making profits.
In 1778, eight Kengyo and two Koto were banished from Edo after forfeiting all of their assets for their excessively underhanded means of making profits.

sen.j: 有名な検校
sen.e: Famous kengyos
Famous Kengyo
Famous Kengyo

sen.j: （）内は関名
sen.e: (): 関名 (head name)
sen.cmt: 関名→意味・読み方不明のため、関名 (first name fro kengyo)としました。
sen.e: When known, 関名 (first name) is enclosed in parenthesis ().
